description.narrative:
Coalition Clean Baltic (CCB) har lämnat in en ansökan till Sida för stöd om 34 MSEK till projektet ”Creating and sustaining positive change in key thematic areas related to water – strengthening the role of NGOs and civil society in Belarus and Russia.” Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att löpa över en period på 3,5 år mellan 2020-2023, och budgeten för Belarus är 21,6 MSEK och för Ryssland 12,4 MSEK. Insatsen är en fortsättning på ett tidigare Sida-finansierat CCB-projekt, ”Strengthening Civil Society Engagement in Water Strategies in Belarus 2016-2020”. (ID:55030185), vilket fokuserat på den miljömässigt dåliga kvalitén på grund- och ytvattnet i Belarus. Den nya föreslagna insatsen är i stort sett baserad på resultat och lärdomar från det tidigare programmet, samt på diskussioner och konsultationer med en rad olika intressenter i Belarus och Ryssland, som frivilligorganisationer, jordbrukare, fiskare, kyrkoförsamlingar samt även med forskningsorgan och beslutsfattare inom hälsa, jordbruk, miljöskydd och utbildning. Förutom den tidigare insatsen i Belarus har CCB också erfarenheter från projekt-genomförande i Ryssland genom programmet ”Building Capacity and Involvement of Civil Society”, vilket är en insats som genomfördes i samverkan mellan CCB, WWF Ryssland och WWF Sverige mellan 2016-2019.
Den föreslagna insatsen planerar att adressera ett flertal utmaningar som identifierats inom vatten-kvalitet och -förvaltning i Ryssland och Belarus. En annat problemområde som kommer att inom programmet är bristande inflytande från allmänheten när det gäller beslutsfattande inom vattensektorn. Dessa underliggande problem kommer att angripas på olika sätt, bland annat genom att öka medvetenheten bland allmänheten, samla in och presentera data och information till beslutsfattare och allmänhet, engagera frivilligorganisationer i en allmän dialog med myndigheter och beslutsfattare, mobilisera och stötta lokala organisationer (allmänhet, jordbrukare och skolor) att kunna delta i praktiska aktiviteter för att övervaka och förbättra vattenkvalitet och – förvaltning. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer också att innehålla ett öppet anbudsförfararande, genom vilket CCB kan ge finansiellt stöd till mindre etablerade gräsrots-organisationer för tematiskt lokalt stöd. Detta görs för att programmet ska kunna få en bredare räckvidd.

Coalition Clean Baltic (CCB) has made a project funding request for a total of roughly 34 million SEK for the project "Creating and sustaining positive change in key thematic areas related to water - strengthening the role of NGOs and civil society in Belarus and Russia”. The proposed programme will run for a period of 3.5 years between 2020-2023, and the budgets for Belarus and Russia are roughly 21.6 and 12.4 MSEK respectively. The intervention is a continuation of a previously Sida-financed CCB project, "Strengthening Civil Society Engagement in Water Strategies in Belarus 2016-2020" (ID: 55030185), targeting the poor ecological status of surface- and ground waters in Belarus. The proposed project's activities are to a large extent based on the results gained and lessons learned from the previous CCB implemented intervention as well as consultations with Belarusian and Russian stakeholders, such as non-governmental (NGOs), farmers, fishermen club members, church communities as well as representatives of decision making and scientific bodies in water management, health, agriculture, environmental protection and education. CCB also has a background of previous activities in Russia through the programme “Building Capacity an Involvement of Civil Society”, a cooperation between CCB, WWF Russia and WWF Sweden, 2016-2019.
The proposed project intends to address a wide range of identified challenges with water quality and management as well as public participation in decision making in Belarus and Russia through several different approaches. These include raising public awareness; collecting, analysing and presenting data and information to policy makers and the public; engaging NGOs and the general public in dialogue with policy makers and authorities; and mobilising and supporting local actors (general public, farmers and schools) to participate in practical efforts to improve and monitor water quality and management. The proposed contribution will also include an open call to CCB for less established Belarusian and Russian grass-root and civil society groups for thematic local support. This in order to increase the reach of the programme.

The CCB intervention "Creating and Sustaining Positive Change in Key Thematic Areas Related to Water- Strengthening the Role of NGOs and Civil Society in Belarus and Russia" will address a wide range of identified challenges with water quality and management, public participation in decision making in Belarus and Russia through a number of different approaches. The Programme will contribute to the following long-term impact: People in Belarus and Russia benefit from well-functioning water management and good environmental practices. There are three outcomes (objectives) of the intervention; The public actively engages towards a positive change in water-related governance and practices including eco-tourism in Belarus and Russia, NGO’s and all relevant stakeholders are working in coordination to improve ecological status of the river basins, to have climate change adaptation measures and to keep promoting and practice organic and sustainable agriculture, Voices and opinion of NGO’s and partners are taken into account in the decision making process. The objectives of the intervention are well in line with the Results strategy for Sweden’s reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014 – 2020. The intervention will specifically contribute towards result 2.6) Improved conditions for democratic accountability to the people and participation in political processes, including the promotion of free elections; and indirectly to 2.9) Women and men have, to a greater extent, the same power to shape society and their own lives. Moreover, the outcomes of the intervention will have direct impact on result 3.2) Enhanced environmental responsibility among the general public, the business sector and civil society; and 3.3) More sustainable public services in areas such as water and sewage, waste management, energy efficiency and renewable energy. According to the plans there will be a new strategy for the Swedish development cooperation with the Eastern Partnership countries Europe from 2021-2027. It is not expected that there will be any major changes regarding the prioritised sectors in the new strategy, which means that the proposed intervention will still be in line with the upcoming new strategy. The contribution further aligns well with the EU Roadmap for Engagement with Civil Society in Belarus (2018-2020), adopted by Sweden, approved 11 September 2018. Support to more participatory decision-making procedures is one of EU's leading themes in the 2018-2020 roadmap. The objectives of the intervention are also in line with the strategy for the Swedish development cooperation with Russia. The intervention will have direct bearing on two out of three expected results for the Environment, Climate and Energy in the Strategy for Sweden's support for democracy, human rights and environment in Russia 2020-2024: 2.1 Strengthened capacity for sustainable management of ecosystems, sustainable management and sustainable use of natural resources, conservation of biodiversity and reduced emissions in the Baltic Sea, and 2.2 Strengthened capacity of civil society and other relevant actors to contribute to a better environment and reduced climate impact.

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 14.1 - By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
14.1 - Till 2025 förebygga och avsevärt minska alla slags föroreningar i havet, i synnerhet från landbaserad verksamhet, inklusive marint skräp och tillförsel av näringsämnen.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.
